Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: How Families Motivate Mexican-Origin Adolescents to Pursue Physical Science in High School

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed CAREER study uses a comprehensive mixed-methods design to develop measures of motivational beliefs and family supports for Spanish and English speaking Mexican-origin youth in high school physical science. The research examines a three-part model which may provide a deeper understanding of how Mexican families support youth through their general education strategies, beliefs about physical science, and science specific behaviors. This approach incorporates motivation and ecodevelopmental theories while pursuing an innovative line of research that examines how the contributions of older siblings and relatives complement or supplement parental support. The study has four aims which are to (1) to develop reliable, valid measures of Mexican-origin adolescent motivational beliefs and family supports in relation to high school chemistry and physics, (2) to test whether family supports predict motivational beliefs and course enrollment, (3) to test how indicators in Aim 2 vary based on gender, culture, English language skills and relationship quality, and ( 4) to examine how family supports strengthen or weaken the relationship between school-based interactions (teachers and peer support) and the pursuit of physical science studies.

Spanish and English-speaking Mexican-origin youth will participate in focus groups to inform the development of a survey instrument which will be used in a statistical measurement equivalence study of 300 high school students in fulfillment of Aim 1. One hundred and fifty Mexican high school students and their families will participate in a longitudinal study while students progress through grades 9-12 to examine Aims 2- 4. Data to be collected includes information on science coursework, adolescent motivational beliefs, supports by mothers and older youth in the family, and family interactions. All materials will be in English and Spanish.

The educational and research integration plan uses a three pronged approach which includes mentoring of doctoral students, teacher outreach, and the evaluation of the ASU Biodesign high school summer internship program using measures resulting from the research. It is anticipated that the study findings will provide research-based solutions to some of the specific behaviors that influence youth motivation in physical sciences. Specifically, the study will identify youth that might be most affected by an intervention and the age of maximum benefit, as well as valid, reliable measures of youths' motivation that can used in interventions to measure outcomes. The study will also identify family behaviors that may be influenced, including education strategies for school preparation, beliefs about physical science, and sciece-specific strategies such as engaging in science activities outside school. The findings will be broadly disseminated to science teachers, scholars, and families of Mexican-origin youth. This multi-tiered approach will advance current scholarship and practice concerning Mexican-origin adolescents' pursuit of physical science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this NSF CAREER research project was to examine the changes in Latinx adolescents’ science motivational beliefs over high school and to test the extent to which parents’ beliefs about science and their support of science predicted adolescents’ science motivational beliefs and outcomes. Because few studies had examined these topics among Latinxs, my first goal, which my team and I achieved, was to develop reliable measures of Latinx adolescents’ motivational beliefs in math, biology, chemistry, and physics, as well as parenting. To test these measures, we collected survey data on 1,200 9th grade high school students. These were published in the Journal for Research on Science Teaching and are freely available in English and Spanish on our website (http://simpkinslab.weebly.com/family--science-project.html). 

 

My second goal was to examine the relations between family support of science and Latinx adolescents’ motivational beliefs over high school. To test these relations, we collected rich data on a subset of 104 Latinx high school students as well as their parent, older sibling, science teacher, and record data during the four years of high school. Survey data were collected from students and their science teachers 9th-11th, from parents and older siblings 9th and 10th, and from their record data all four years. In addition, we have qualitative interviews with students, parents, and siblings in 10th grade, and video-taped interaction data between the students, parents, and siblings in 9th and 10th grade. We have begun to use these data to examine the change in adolescents’ motivational beliefs over time and whether parents’ beliefs and support matters for adolescents’ science motivational beliefs and outcomes.

 

Across our analyses, we have several key findings that broadens the current literature on parenting and adolescents’ motivation. First, what Latinx parents believe and do matters for high school students’ science motivational beliefs and outcomes. For example, in one study we tested whether support from parents, siblings, teachers, and friends predicted adolescents’ science motivational beliefs. Although adolescents reported high support from teachers, teacher support alone was not a strong correlate of their motivational beliefs. Feeling supported across home and school may be necessary to sustain adolescents’ science motivational beliefs which, in turn, predicted their engagement in science class. In another study, we took a closer look at parents to examine which beliefs and supports mattered. Latinx parents’ value of science, but not their beliefs about their adolescents’ science abilities predicted their subsequent support. In other words, parents who felt science is valuable supported their adolescent in science regardless of their perceptions of adolescents’ science abilities. Parents’ support, in turn, predicted increases in adolescents’ beliefs about their science abilities. These findings suggest that family involvement at home matters for Latinx high school students. However, our findings suggest that these processes may be somewhat different for Latinx boys and girls. For example, Latinx parents in this study were less likely to act on their value of science if they were parents of girls compared to parents of boys, which contradicts previous research. One possibility is that the masculine stereotypes about science coupled with traditional gender roles emphasized in Latinx culture could create counter-productive mechanisms for girls in science. Another possibility for these differential transactional processes is due to girls’ typically more advanced maturity and higher academic achievement compared to boys. Parents may begin pulling back their support if they believe girls do not need their support to achieve. Parent support was equally valuable for girls’ and boys’ beliefs about their science abilities.  

 

These findings have been disseminated to academic audiences through four journal articles, four chapters, and sixteen conference presentations. We have also disseminated our work beyond traditional academic audiences through our website, state science teacher associations through three newsletter articles, and other STEM organizations that work with families, including museums and organized after-school activities.

 

Through the educational component of this award, several outcomes were achieved. As noted earlier, the work was broadly disseminated to raise awareness among families, teachers, and after-school stakeholders in regard to the importance of motivational beliefs as a key determinant of their STEM pursuits and the continued importance of families during high school. In addition, this project provided several opportunities for students underrepresented in the STEM pipeline to gain vital skills to succeed in the next phase of their careers (such as, writing grants, mentoring young scholars, the advantages of qualitative and quantitative research methods) and how to promote equity and diversity in STEM.
